PACC/Util/MTRand.hpp

00001 // MTRand.hpp
00002 // Mersenne Twister random number generator -- a C++ class MTRand
00003 // Based on code by Makoto Matsumoto, Takuji Nishimura, and Shawn Cokus
00004 // Richard J. Wagner  v1.0  15 May 2003  rjwagner@writeme.com
00005 
00006 // The Mersenne Twister is an algorithm for generating random numbers.  It
00007 // was designed with consideration of the flaws in various other generators.
00008 // The period, 2^19937-1, and the order of equidistribution, 623 dimensions,
00009 // are far greater.  The generator is also fast; it avoids multiplication and
00010 // division, and it benefits from caches and pipelines.  For more information
00011 // see the inventors' web page at http://www.math.keio.ac.jp/~matumoto/emt.html
00012 
00013 // Reference
00014 // M. Matsumoto and T. Nishimura, "Mersenne Twister: A 623-Dimensionally
00015 // Equidistributed Uniform Pseudo-Random Number Generator", ACM Transactions on
00016 // Modeling and Computer Simulation, Vol. 8, No. 1, January 1998, pp 3-30.
00017 
00018 // Copyright (C) 1997 - 2002, Makoto Matsumoto and Takuji Nishimura,
00019 // Copyright (C) 2000 - 2003, Richard J. Wagner
00020 // All rights reserved.                          
00021 //
00022 // Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without
00023 // modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions
00024 // are met:
00025 //

00027 //      notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer.
00028 //
00029 //   2. Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above copyright
00030 //      notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer in the
00031 //      documentation and/or other materials provided with the distribution.
00032 //
00033 //   3. The names of its contributors may not be used to endorse or promote 
00034 //      products derived from this software without specific prior written 
00035 //      permission.

00057 #ifndef MersenneTwister_hpp_
00058 #define MersenneTwister_hpp_

00060 #include <climits>
00061 #include <cmath>
00062 #include <iostream>
00063 #include <stdio.h>
00064 #include <time.h>

00074 class MTRand {
00075     // Data
00076     public:
00077     typedef unsigned long uint32;  
00078     
00080     enum { N = 624 };   
00082     enum { SAVE = N + 1 };  
00083     
00084     protected:
00086     enum { M = 397 };  
00087     
00088     uint32 state[N];   
00089     uint32 *pNext;     
00090     uint32 left;          
00091     
00092     
00093     //Methods
00094     public:
00096     MTRand(const uint32& oneSeed); 
00098     MTRand(const uint32 *const bigSeed, uint32 const seedLength = N );
00105     MTRand(void);  
00106     
00107     // Access to 32-bit random numbers
00108     double rand(void);                      
00109     double rand(const double& n);           
00110     double randExc(void);                   
00111     double randExc(const double& n);        
00112     double randDblExc(void);                
00113     double randDblExc(const double& n);     
00114     uint32 randInt(void);                   
00115     uint32 randInt(const uint32& n);        
00116     double operator()(void) {return rand();}
00117     
00119     double rand53();  // 
00120     
00122     double randNorm( const double& mean = 0.0, const double& variance = 0.0 );
00123     
00125     void seed( const uint32 oneSeed );
00127     void seed( const uint32 *const bigSeed, const uint32 seedLength = N );
00129     void seed();
00130     
00132     void save( uint32* saveArray ) const;  // to array of size SAVE
00134     void load( uint32 *const loadArray );  // from such array
00135     
00137     friend std::ostream& operator<<( std::ostream& os, const MTRand& mtrand );
00139     friend std::istream& operator>>( std::istream& is, MTRand& mtrand );
00140     
00141     protected:
00142     void initialize( const uint32 oneSeed );
00143     void reload();
00144     uint32 hiBit( const uint32& u ) const { return u & 0x80000000UL; }
00145     uint32 loBit( const uint32& u ) const { return u & 0x00000001UL; }
00146     uint32 loBits( const uint32& u ) const { return u & 0x7fffffffUL; }
00147     uint32 mixBits( const uint32& u, const uint32& v ) const
00148     { return hiBit(u) | loBits(v); }
00149     uint32 twist( const uint32& m, const uint32& s0, const uint32& s1 ) const
00150     { return m ^ (mixBits(s0,s1)>>1) ^ (-loBit(s1) & 0x9908b0dfUL); }
00151     static uint32 hash( time_t t, clock_t c );
00152 };

00155 inline MTRand::MTRand( const uint32& oneSeed )
00156 { seed(oneSeed); }
00157 
00158 inline MTRand::MTRand( const uint32 *const bigSeed, const uint32 seedLength )
00159 { seed(bigSeed,seedLength); }
00160 
00161 inline MTRand::MTRand()
00162 { seed(); }

00164 inline double MTRand::rand()
00165 { return double(randInt()) * (1.0/4294967295.0); }
00166 
00167 inline double MTRand::rand( const double& n )
00168 { return rand() * n; }
00169 
00170 inline double MTRand::randExc()
00171 { return double(randInt()) * (1.0/4294967296.0); }
00172 
00173 inline double MTRand::randExc( const double& n )
00174 { return randExc() * n; }
00175 
00176 inline double MTRand::randDblExc()
00177 { return ( double(randInt()) + 0.5 ) * (1.0/4294967296.0); }
00178 
00179 inline double MTRand::randDblExc( const double& n )
00180 { return randDblExc() * n; }
00181 
00182 inline double MTRand::rand53()
00183 {
00184     uint32 a = randInt() >> 5, b = randInt() >> 6;
00185     return ( a * 67108864.0 + b ) * (1.0/9007199254740992.0);  // by Isaku Wada
00186 }
00187 
00188 inline double MTRand::randNorm( const double& mean, const double& variance )
00189 {
00190     // Return a real number from a normal (Gaussian) distribution with given
00191     // mean and variance by Box-Muller method
00192     // see http://www.dspguru.com/howto/tech/wgn2.htm
00193     // Added by M. Parizeau: the variance argument is in fact a standard deviation
00194     double r = sqrt( -2.0 * log( 1.0-randDblExc()) ) * variance;
00195     double phi = 2.0 * 3.14159265358979323846264338328 * randExc();
00196     return mean + r * cos(phi);
00197 }
00198 
00199 inline MTRand::uint32 MTRand::randInt()
00200 {
00201     // Pull a 32-bit integer from the generator state
00202     // Every other access function simply transforms the numbers extracted here
00203     
00204     if( left == 0 ) reload();
00205     --left;
00206     
00207     register uint32 s1;
00208     s1 = *pNext++;
00209     s1 ^= (s1 >> 11);
00210     s1 ^= (s1 <<  7) & 0x9d2c5680UL;
00211     s1 ^= (s1 << 15) & 0xefc60000UL;
00212     return ( s1 ^ (s1 >> 18) );
00213 }
00214 
00215 inline MTRand::uint32 MTRand::randInt( const uint32& n )
00216 {
00217     // Find which bits are used in n
00218     // Optimized by Magnus Jonsson (magnus@smartelectronix.com)
00219     uint32 used = n;
00220     used |= used >> 1;
00221     used |= used >> 2;
00222     used |= used >> 4;
00223     used |= used >> 8;
00224     used |= used >> 16;
00225     
00226     // Draw numbers until one is found in [0,n]
00227     uint32 i;
00228     do
00229         i = randInt() & used;  // toss unused bits to shorten search
00230     while( i > n );
00231     return i;
00232 }

00235 inline void MTRand::seed( const uint32 oneSeed )
00236 {
00237     // Seed the generator with a simple uint32
00238     initialize(oneSeed);
00239     reload();
00240 }
00241 
00242 
00243 inline void MTRand::seed( const uint32 *const bigSeed, const uint32 seedLength )
00244 {
00245     // Seed the generator with an array of uint32's
00246     // There are 2^19937-1 possible initial states.  This function allows
00247     // all of those to be accessed by providing at least 19937 bits (with a
00248     // default seed length of N = 624 uint32's).  Any bits above the lower 32
00249     // in each element are discarded.
00250     // Just call seed() if you want to get array from /dev/urandom
00251     initialize(19650218UL);
00252     register int i = 1;
00253     register uint32 j = 0;
00254     register uint32 k = ( (uint32)N > seedLength ? (uint32)N : seedLength );
00255     for( ; k; --k )
00256     {
00257         state[i] =
00258         state[i] ^ ( (state[i-1] ^ (state[i-1] >> 30)) * 1664525UL );
00259         state[i] += ( bigSeed[j] & 0xffffffffUL ) + j;
00260         state[i] &= 0xffffffffUL;
00261         ++i;  ++j;
00262         if( i >= N ) { state[0] = state[N-1];  i = 1; }
00263         if( j >= seedLength ) j = 0;
00264     }
00265     for( k = N - 1; k; --k )
00266     {
00267         state[i] =
00268         state[i] ^ ( (state[i-1] ^ (state[i-1] >> 30)) * 1566083941UL );
00269         state[i] -= i;
00270         state[i] &= 0xffffffffUL;
00271         ++i;
00272         if( i >= N ) { state[0] = state[N-1];  i = 1; }
00273     }
00274     state[0] = 0x80000000UL;  // MSB is 1, assuring non-zero initial array
00275     reload();
00276 }
00277 
00278 
00279 inline void MTRand::seed(void)
00280 {
00281     // Seed the generator with an array from /dev/urandom if available
00282     // Otherwise use a hash of time() and clock() values
00283     
00284     // First try getting an array from /dev/urandom
00285     FILE* urandom = fopen( "/dev/urandom", "rb" );
00286     if( urandom )
00287     {
00288         uint32 bigSeed[N];
00289         register uint32 *s = bigSeed;
00290         register int i = N;
00291         register bool success = true;
00292         while( success && i-- )
00293             success = fread( s++, sizeof(uint32), 1, urandom );
00294         fclose(urandom);
00295         if( success ) { seed( bigSeed, N );  return; }
00296     }
00297     
00298     // Was not successful, so use time() and clock() instead
00299     seed( hash( time(NULL), clock() ) );
00300 }
00301 
00302 
00303 inline void MTRand::initialize( const uint32 inSeed )
00304 {
00305     // Initialize generator state with seed
00306     // See Knuth TAOCP Vol 2, 3rd Ed, p.106 for multiplier.
00307     // In previous versions, most significant bits (MSBs) of the seed affect
00308     // only MSBs of the state array.  Modified 9 Jan 2002 by Makoto Matsumoto.
00309     register uint32 *s = state;
00310     register uint32 *r = state;
00311     register int i = 1;
00312     *s++ = inSeed & 0xffffffffUL;
00313     for( ; i < N; ++i )
00314     {
00315         *s++ = ( 1812433253UL * ( *r ^ (*r >> 30) ) + i ) & 0xffffffffUL;
00316         r++;
00317     }
00318 }
00319 
00320 
00321 inline void MTRand::reload(void)
00322 {
00323     // Generate N new values in state
00324     // Made clearer and faster by Matthew Bellew (matthew.bellew@home.com)
00325     register uint32 *p = state;
00326     register int i;
00327     for( i = N - M; i--; ++p )
00328         *p = twist( p[M], p[0], p[1] );
00329     for( i = M; --i; ++p )
00330         *p = twist( p[M-N], p[0], p[1] );
00331     *p = twist( p[M-N], p[0], state[0] );
00332     
00333     left = N, pNext = state;
00334 }
00335 
00336 
00337 inline MTRand::uint32 MTRand::hash( time_t t, clock_t c )
00338 {
00339     // Get a uint32 from t and c
00340     // Better than uint32(x) in case x is floating point in [0,1]
00341     // Based on code by Lawrence Kirby (fred@genesis.demon.co.uk)
00342     
00343     static uint32 differ = 0;  // guarantee time-based seeds will change
00344     
00345     uint32 h1 = 0;
00346     unsigned char *p = (unsigned char *) &t;
00347     for( size_t i = 0; i < sizeof(t); ++i )
00348     {
00349         h1 *= UCHAR_MAX + 2U;
00350         h1 += p[i];
00351     }
00352     uint32 h2 = 0;
00353     p = (unsigned char *) &c;
00354     for( size_t j = 0; j < sizeof(c); ++j )
00355     {
00356         h2 *= UCHAR_MAX + 2U;
00357         h2 += p[j];
00358     }
00359     return ( h1 + differ++ ) ^ h2;
00360 }
00361 
00362 
00363 inline void MTRand::save( uint32* saveArray ) const
00364 {
00365     register uint32 *sa = saveArray;
00366     register const uint32 *s = state;
00367     register int i = N;
00368     for( ; i--; *sa++ = *s++ ) {}
00369     *sa = left;
00370 }
00371 
00372 
00373 inline void MTRand::load( uint32 *const loadArray )
00374 {
00375     register uint32 *s = state;
00376     register uint32 *la = loadArray;
00377     register int i = N;
00378     for( ; i--; *s++ = *la++ ) {}
00379     left = *la;
00380     pNext = &state[N-left];
00381 }
00382 
00383 
00384 inline std::ostream& operator<<( std::ostream& os, const MTRand& mtrand )
00385 {
00386     register const MTRand::uint32 *s = mtrand.state;
00387     register int i = mtrand.N;
00388     for( ; i--; os << *s++ << "\t" ) {}
00389     return os << mtrand.left;
00390 }
00391 
00392 
00393 inline std::istream& operator>>( std::istream& is, MTRand& mtrand )
00394 {
00395     register MTRand::uint32 *s = mtrand.state;
00396     register int i = mtrand.N;
00397     for( ; i--; is >> *s++ ) {}
00398     is >> mtrand.left;
00399     mtrand.pNext = &mtrand.state[mtrand.N-mtrand.left];
00400     return is;
00401 }

00405 // Change log:
00406 //
00407 // v0.1 - First release on 15 May 2000
00408 //      - Based on code by Makoto Matsumoto, Takuji Nishimura, and Shawn Cokus
00409 //      - Translated from C to C++
00410 //      - Made completely ANSI compliant
00411 //      - Designed convenient interface for initialization, seeding, and
00412 //        obtaining numbers in default or user-defined ranges
00413 //      - Added automatic seeding from /dev/urandom or time() and clock()
00414 //      - Provided functions for saving and loading generator state
00415 //
00416 // v0.2 - Fixed bug which reloaded generator one step too late
00417 //
00418 // v0.3 - Switched to clearer, faster reload() code from Matthew Bellew
00419 //
00420 // v0.4 - Removed trailing newline in saved generator format to be consistent
00421 //        with output format of built-in types
00422 //
00423 // v0.5 - Improved portability by replacing static const int's with enum's and
00424 //        clarifying return values in seed(); suggested by Eric Heimburg
00425 //      - Removed MAXINT constant; use 0xffffffffUL instead
00426 //
00427 // v0.6 - Eliminated seed overflow when uint32 is larger than 32 bits
00428 //      - Changed integer [0,n] generator to give better uniformity
00429 //
00430 // v0.7 - Fixed operator precedence ambiguity in reload()
00431 //      - Added access for real numbers in (0,1) and (0,n)
00432 //
00433 // v0.8 - Included time.h header to properly support time_t and clock_t
00434 //
00435 // v1.0 - Revised seeding to match 26 Jan 2002 update of Nishimura and Matsumoto
00436 //      - Allowed for seeding with arrays of any length
00437 //      - Added access for real numbers in [0,1) with 53-bit resolution
00438 //      - Added access for real numbers from normal (Gaussian) distributions
00439 //      - Increased overall speed by optimizing twist()
00440 //      - Doubled speed of integer [0,n] generation
00441 //      - Fixed out-of-range number generation on 64-bit machines
00442 //      - Improved portability by substituting literal constants for long enum's
00443 //      - Changed license from GNU LGPL to BSD
